facts.text: Hazarilal, predecessor of respondents 1 to 5, and Jagat Narain, respondent 6, executed a simple mortgage deed for Rs. 50,000 on January 17, 1946.

facts.text: Mortgage interest rate was 9% per annum, or in default of payment for 3 months, Re. 1 per cent per month for the period of default.

anchor.surface_text: executed a simple mortgage deed for Rs. 50,000 with interest at 9 per annum or in default of payment of interest for 3 months at Re. 1 per cent per month for the period of default.

facts.text: Mortgagors made default in payment of interest and did not pay anything out of the mortgaged amount.

anchor.surface_text: As the mortgagors made default in payment of interest and also did number pay anything out of the mortgaged amount a suit was filed for enforcement of the mortgage by sale of properties.

anchor.surface_text: Court fee was paid on Rs. 7,900. During the pendency of this appeal the decree was made final on April 3, 1954.

facts.text: Inderjit and Satya Narain, sons of Hazarilal, filed a suit declaring properties ancestral and joint family, seeking injunction against sale.

issues.text: whether the provisions of ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act could be invoked by the Divisional Bench to reduce the interest as stated above

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore, to decide whether the provisions of ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act could be invoked by the Divisional Bench to reduce the interest as stated above. The amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act is plainly mandatory because it makes it obligatory for a court to re- open a transaction if there is reason to believe that the interest is excessive.

issues.text: whether s. 5 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act can only apply to a suit instituted or pending after the section comes into force and not in an appeal after the suit has ended in a decree

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal it is contended on behalf of the decree holder- that s. 5 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act can only apply to a suit instituted or pending after the section comes -into force and not in an appeal after the suit has ended in a decree. It is farther contended that this will be all the more so, because the section itself is made retrospective for suits pending on or instituted after the commencement of the Act and thus cannot affect the vested right which the judgment had given to the appellants.

issues.text: whether the suit could be said to be pending on June 8, 1956 when only an appeal from the judgment in the suit was pending

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act is clearly retrospective. Indeed, the heading of the section shows that it lays down the retrospective effect. This being so, the core of the problem really is whether the suit could be said to be pending on June 8, 1956 when only an appeal from the judgment in the suit was pending.

issues.text: whether the word suit includes an appeal from the judgment in the suit

anchor.surface_text: This requires the consideration whether the word suit includes an appeal from the judgment in the suit. An appeal has been said to be the right of entering a superior court, and invoking its aid and interposition to redress the error of the court below.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in reducing interest in a preliminary mortgage decree dated August 12, 1953 by applying ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act which were extended to Delhi on June 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: the only question is whether, in the facts to be stated presently, the High Court was right in reducing interest in a preliminary mortgage decree dated August 12, 1953 by applying ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act which were extended to Delhi on June 8, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended s.3 mandatory and retrospective via s.6; appeal continuation of pending suit allowing application.

holdings.text: The amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act is plainly mandatory because it makes it obligatory for a court to re-open a transaction if there is reason to believe that the interest is excessive.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore, to decide whether the provisions of ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act could be invoked by the Divisional Bench to reduce the interest as stated above. The amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act is plainly mandatory because it makes it obligatory for a court to re- open a transaction if there is reason to believe that the interest is excessive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substitution of 'shall' for 'may' imposes obligation on court.

holdings.text: Where the rate of interest exceeds seven and a half per centum per annum simple, the court must hold that it is excessive.

anchor.surface_text: Further, where the rate of interest exceeds seven and a half, percentum per annum simple, the court must hold that it is excessive. Therefore if the amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act applies to the case in hand, the High Court was right in acting as it did.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Added clause in s.5 deems such interest excessive.

holdings.text: Section 6 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act is clearly retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act is clearly retrospective. Indeed, the heading of the section shows that it lays down the retrospective effect. This being so, the core of the problem really is whether the suit could be said to be pending on June 8, 1956 when only an appeal from the judgment in the suit was pending.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heading and text expressly provide for application to pending suits.

holdings.text: The suit could be said to be pending on June 8, 1956 when only an appeal from the judgment in the suit was pending.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act is clearly retrospective. Indeed, the heading of the section shows that it lays down the retrospective effect. holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal stage part of pending suit; avoids anomaly.

holdings.text: The word 'suit' includes an appeal from the judgment in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: This requires the consideration whether the word suit includes an appeal from the judgment in the suit. An appeal has been said to be the right of entering a superior court, and invoking its aid and interposition to redress the error of the court below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal reviews and corrects original proceedings; part of cause.

holdings.text: An appeal is a continuation of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Now as a general proposition, it may be admitted that ordinarily a court of appeal cannot take into account a new law, brought into existence after the judgment appealed from has been tendered, because the rights of the litigants in an appeal are determined under the law in force at the date of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established doctrine; appeal interferes in existing cause.

holdings.text: A preliminary decree in a suit of this kind does not terminate the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the present Act the intention is to give relief in respect of excessive interest in a suit which is pending and a preliminary decree in a suit of this kind does not terminate the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit remains pending until final decree; appeal determines final preliminary decree.

holdings.text: In speaking of a pending suit, the legislature was thinking not only in terms of the suit proper but also of those stages in the life of the suit which ordinarily take place before a final executable document comes into existence... a live suit whether in the court of first instance or in an appeal court.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, appear that in speaking of a pending suit, the legislature was thinking not only in terms of the suit proper but also of those stages in the life of the suit which ordinarily take place before a final executable document comes into existence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation; excludes only suits with final executable decree.

holdings.text: The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act as amended to the case.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act  as amended  to the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All sub-issues resolved in favor of application.

anchor.surface_text: the only question is whether, in the facts to be stated presently, the High Court was right in reducing interest in a preliminary mortgage decree dated August 12, 1953 by applying ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act which were extended to Delhi on June 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore, to decide whether the provisions of ss. 5 and 6 of the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act could be invoked by the Divisional Bench to reduce the interest as stated above. The amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act is plainly mandatory because it makes it obligatory for a court to re- open a transaction if there is reason to believe that the interest is excessive.
The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act  as amended  to the case.

anchor.surface_text: Further, where the rate of interest exceeds seven and a half, percentum per annum simple, the court must hold that it is excessive. Therefore if the amended section 3 of the Usurious Loans Act applies to the case in hand, the High Court was right in acting as it did.
The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act  as amended  to the case.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 of the Relief of Indebtedness Act is clearly retrospective. Indeed, the heading of the section shows that it lays down the retrospective effect. This being so, the core of the problem really is whether the suit could be said to be pending on June 8, 1956 when only an appeal from the judgment in the suit was pending.
The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act  as amended  to the case.

anchor.surface_text: Now as a general proposition, it may be admitted that ordinarily a court of appeal cannot take into account a new law, brought into existence after the judgment appealed from has been tendered, because the rights of the litigants in an appeal are determined under the law in force at the date of the suit.
The decision of the High Court was right in applying s. 3 of the Usurious Loans Act  as amended  to the case.

anchor.surface_text: In the present Act the intention is to give relief in respect of excessive interest in a suit which is pending and a preliminary decree in a suit of this kind does not terminate the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, appear that in speaking of a pending suit, the legislature was thinking not only in terms of the suit proper but also of those stages in the life of the suit which ordinarily take place before a final executable document comes into existence.
